case_id: State of Punjab v. Ramdev Singh (2003) 11 SCC 371
facts: Incident occurred on August 17, 1994, around 10:00 PM near the house of Gurdial Singh (deceased) in Village Bhaini Bagha, District Mansa, Punjab.
Complainant Gurjant Singh (PW-4) and the deceased Gurdial Singh were returning to their house.
Accused Ramdev Singh (respondent), Gurdial Singh s/o Bachan Singh, Gurjant Singh, Mander Singh, and Bachittar Singh were allegedly waiting near the deceased's house, armed with weapons.
Ramdev Singh was armed with a gandasi (a sharp-edged weapon), while the others carried sotas (lathis/blunt weapons).
Ramdev Singh inflicted a gandasi blow on the head of Gurdial Singh (deceased).
The other accused allegedly assaulted Gurdial Singh with sotas.
PW-4 raised an alarm, attracting witnesses PW-5 Jarnail Singh and PW-6 Sadhu Singh.

Gurdial Singh was taken to Civil Hospital, Mansa. Dr. Tilak Raj (PW-1) prepared the Medico-Legal Report (MLR), noting multiple injuries. Injury No. 1, an incised wound on the head attributed to a sharp weapon, was declared dangerous to life.
FIR was registered based on PW-4's statement at PS Sadar Mansa.
Gurdial Singh succumbed to his injuries on August 21, 1994, at Rajindra Hospital, Patiala.
Dr. O.P. Aggarwal (PW-2) conducted the post-mortem, opining death was due to head injury and its complications.
Motive alleged was a land dispute.
Trial Court convicted all five accused under Section 302 read with Section 149 IPC and Section 148 IPC, sentencing them to life imprisonment and 1 year RI respectively.
On appeal, the High Court acquitted Gurdial Singh s/o Bachan Singh, Gurjant Singh, Mander Singh, and Bachittar Singh.
The High Court altered Ramdev Singh's conviction from Section 302 IPC to Section 304 Part I IPC and sentenced him to 10 years Rigorous Imprisonment.
The State of Punjab appealed to the Supreme Court against the acquittal of the four accused and the alteration of Ramdev Singh's conviction.
ipc_sections: Section 149 (Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object)
Section 304 Part I (Punishment for Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - act done with intention of causing death, or causing bodily injury likely to cause death)
Section 304 Part II (Punishment for Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - act done with knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without intention)
Section 326 (Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means - potentially relevant if intent for murder/culpable homicide not proven)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in altering Ramdev Singh's conviction from Section 302 IPC to Section 304 Part I IPC. The act squarely falls under Section 300 Clause Thirdly (Murder).
precedents: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1958 SC 465): Established the test for Clause Thirdly of Section 300 - Intention to cause the specific bodily injury, and that injury being sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

Anda v. State of Rajasthan (AIR 1966 SC 148): A single blow, depending on the nature of the weapon, the force used, and the part of the body struck, can be sufficient to prove intention to cause death or injury sufficient to cause death (Sec 300).
State of Karnataka v. Shivalinga (2001) 9 SCC 330: Injury on a vital part like the head with a lethal weapon like a gandasi indicates intention satisfying Sec 300, Clause Thirdly.
elements: Accused (Ramdev Singh) caused bodily injury to the deceased.
The injury was intentionally inflicted by the accused.
The specific injury intended to be inflicted was inflicted.
The injury, objectively assessed, was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death (supported by medical evidence PW-1, PW-2).

counter_arguments.loophole: The act involved a single blow by Ramdev Singh, which might suggest lack of determined intention to kill, potentially placing it under Section 304 Part I or II.
supporting_precedents: Jagrup Singh v. State of Haryana (1981) 3 SCC 616: Single blow in sudden fight context often leads to Section 304 conviction. (Distinguishable here due to ambush).
Gurmail Singh v. State of Punjab (1991) 1 SCC 189: Single blow cases require careful consideration of weapon, body part, force; conviction can be under 302 or 304.

Chamru Budhwa v. State of Madhya Pradesh (AIR 1954 SC 652): If intention was merely to cause grievous hurt, even if death resulted, it might not be murder. (Prosecution counters with weapon choice and vital part).

prosecution_arguments.argument: The evidence of eyewitnesses (PW-4, PW-5, PW-6) is credible and consistent regarding Ramdev Singh's role in delivering the fatal blow with the gandasi.
precedents: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1953 SC 364): Relationship is not a factor affecting credibility unless bias is proven; evidence needs careful scrutiny.
Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras (AIR 1957 SC 614): Testimony of a single eyewitness can be sufficient for conviction if found wholly reliable.
State of U.P. v. Anil Singh (AIR 1988 SC 1998): Minor discrepancies in witness accounts do not necessarily discredit their entire testimony if the core narrative is consistent.
elements: Presence of witnesses at the scene.
Opportunity for witnesses to observe the incident.
Consistency in deposition regarding Ramdev Singh's specific act.
Corroboration of eyewitness accounts by medical evidence (nature and location of Injury No. 1).

counter_arguments.loophole: PW-4, PW-5, PW-6 might be considered interested or related witnesses due to village factions/land dispute, potentially exaggerating the incident.
supporting_precedents: M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691: Evidence of interested witnesses requires caution and preferably corroboration from independent sources.
Hari Obula Reddy v. State of A.P. (1981) 3 SCC 675: Court must be cautious if witnesses have motive for false implication.
Bihari Nath Aggarwal v. State of Assam (1994) Supp (1) SCC 555: Inconsistencies on material particulars can render related witness testimony unreliable.

prosecution_arguments.argument: The acquittal of the other four accused by the High Court does not preclude Ramdev Singh's conviction for murder, as his individual act caused the death.
precedents: Brathi v. State of Punjab (1991) 1 SCC 519: If evidence shows specific fatal injury caused by one accused, that individual can be convicted even if common object/intention (Sec 149/34) not proven against others.
Harbans Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1962 SC 439): Acquittal of co-accused does not automatically lead to acquittal of another if direct evidence implicates the latter.

Yogesh Singh v. Mahabeer Singh (2017) 11 SCC 195: Even if unlawful assembly (149) or common intention (34) fails, individual liability under Sec 302 can be fixed based on specific role and injury caused.
elements: Specific overt act by Ramdev Singh (gandasi blow to head).
Causal link between Ramdev Singh's act and the death (medical evidence).
Distinction between individual liability and vicarious liability (Sec 149/34).

counter_arguments.loophole: If the entire prosecution story of a concerted attack by an unlawful assembly is disbelieved (leading to acquittal of others), it might cast doubt on the genesis of the incident and the credibility of witnesses regarding Ramdev Singh's role as well.
supporting_precedents: Marachalil Pakku v. State of Madras (AIR 1954 SC 648): When substratum of prosecution case (e.g., assembly/common object) collapses, conviction of individual accused needs very strong independent evidence.
Zwinglee Ariel v. State of Madhya Pradesh (AIR 1954 SC 15): If main part of story is disbelieved, careful consideration needed before accepting residual part.
Piara Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1977 SC 2274): If prosecution case regarding participation of several accused is false, entire case may be viewed with suspicion.

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court rightly concluded that the offence committed by Ramdev Singh does not amount to murder (Section 302) but falls under Culpable Homicide Not Amounting to Murder (Section 304 Part I), as the requisite intention for murder was not proven beyond reasonable doubt.
edge_cases: Distinguishing intention to cause death (Sec 300 Cl 1) / intention to cause injury sufficient to cause death (Sec 300 Cl 3) from intention to cause injury likely to cause death (Sec 304 Part I) or knowledge that death is likely (Sec 304 Part II).
Significance of a single blow versus multiple blows in assessing intent.
precedents: State of A.P. v. Rayavarapu Punnayya (1976) 4 SCC 382: Detailed analysis of distinction between Sec 299 and Sec 300 IPC.
Gurmail Singh v. State of Punjab (1991) 1 SCC 189: Single vital injury case where SC upheld 304 Part I, emphasizing need to assess all circumstances.

Tholan v. State of Tamil Nadu (1984) 2 SCC 133: Factors like lack of pre-meditation (arguable despite ambush claim), nature of quarrel, single blow, can justify conviction under Sec 304 instead of 302.

defense_arguments.argument: The prosecution witnesses (PW-4, PW-5, PW-6) are interested and partisan due to the admitted land dispute, and their testimony should not be relied upon without independent corroboration, which is lacking.
edge_cases: Impact of admitted enmity between parties on witness credibility.
precedents: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1953 SC 364): Emphasizes need for careful scrutiny of related/interested witnesses.
M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691: Caution required, corroboration preferred for interested witnesses.
State of Punjab v. Jagir Singh (AIR 1973 SC 2407): Where witnesses are shown to have strong motives for false implication (enmity), corroboration is essential.

defense_arguments.argument: The medical evidence, while confirming death due to head injury, does not conclusively establish the *intention* required for Section 302 IPC. The injury, though dangerous, might have been inflicted with the intention of causing grievous hurt (Sec 326) or with knowledge but not intention (Sec 304 Part II).
edge_cases: Medical opinion describes the injury's effect ('dangerous', 'sufficient to cause death') but cannot definitively state the accused's subjective intent.
Interplay between objective nature of injury and subjective intent required by law.
precedents: Jai Prakash v. State (Delhi Administration) (1991) 2 SCC 32: Intention must be gathered from all facts - weapon, nature of injury, part of body. Medical evidence is crucial but not sole determinant of intent.
Rampal Singh v. State of U.P. (2012) 8 SCC 289: Intention vs Knowledge distinction - knowledge implies awareness of consequences, intention implies aiming for that consequence.

Kesar Singh v. State of Haryana (2008) 15 SCC 753: If intention was only to cause grievous hurt, Sec 326 applies even if death occurs, unless Sec 300 Exception applies or knowledge under 304 Part II is proven.

judgment.outcome: Appeal by State allowed in part. High Court judgment modified. Ramdev Singh convicted under Section 302 IPC and sentenced to imprisonment for life. Acquittal of other accused by High Court upheld.
reasoning: The Supreme Court held that the High Court erred in altering Ramdev Singh's conviction from Section 302 to 304 Part I IPC.
Applying the principles laid down in Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab, the Court found that Ramdev Singh intentionally inflicted the gandasi blow on the head (a vital part) of the deceased.
The medical evidence (PW-1, PW-2) established that this particular injury was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.
Therefore, all ingredients of Section 300 Clause Thirdly were satisfied, making the offence Murder punishable under Section 302 IPC.

The fact that it was a single blow did not mitigate the offence in this case, given the nature of the weapon used (gandasi), the choice of a vital body part (head), and the severity of the injury inflicted.
The evidence of eyewitnesses regarding Ramdev Singh's role was found credible by the Trial Court and improperly discarded/re-interpreted by the High Court regarding the nature of the offence.

The Supreme Court found no reason to interfere with the High Court's acquittal of the other four accused, presumably due to insufficient evidence to prove their common object extended to murder under Section 149 IPC, or lack of specific evidence linking their individual acts to the fatal outcome.
